name.text: 18.4.2.1 Measuring the height of a building

questiontext.text:
Engineering example

The height \(h\) of a building is estimated from

  1. the known horizontal distance \(x\) between the point of observation \(M\) and the foot of the building and
  2. the elevation angle \(\theta\) between the horizontal and the line joining the point of observation to the top of the building (see Figure below).

If the measured horizontal distance is \(x = 150 \text{m}\) and the elevation angle is \(\theta = 40^{\circ}\), estimate the error in measured building height due to an error of \(0.1^{\circ}\) degree in the measurement of the angle of elevation.

The variables \(x, \theta\), and \(h\) are related by \[\tan \theta = \dfrac{h}{x}\] or \[x \tan \theta = h.\]

The error in \(h\) resulting from a measurement error in \(\theta\) can be deduced by differentiating \(x \tan \theta = h\) as follows. \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}(x \tan \theta)}{\mathrm{d} \theta} = \dfrac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} \theta} \quad \implies \quad \tan \theta \dfrac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} \theta} + x \dfrac{\mathrm{d}(\tan \theta)}{\mathrm{d} \theta} = \dfrac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} \theta}.\] This can be written \[\tan \theta \dfrac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} \theta} + x \sec^2 \theta = \dfrac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} \theta}.\]

The equation above gives the relationship among the small variations in variables \(x, h\) and \(\theta\). Since \(x\) is assumed to be without error and independent of \(\theta\), \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d} \theta} = 0\) and the equation becomes \[x \sec^2 \theta = \dfrac{\mathrm{d}h}{\mathrm{d} \theta}.\]

The above equation can be considered to relate the error in building height \(\delta h\) to the error in angle \(\delta \theta\): \[\dfrac{\delta h}{\delta \theta} \simeq x \sec^2 \theta.\]

It is given that \(x = 150 \text{m}\).

The incidence angle \(\theta = 40^{\circ}\) can be converted to radians i.e \(\theta = \dfrac{40 \pi}{180} \text{ rad} = \dfrac{2 \pi}{9} \text{ rad}\).

Then the error in angle \(\delta \theta = 0.1^{\circ}\) needs to be expressed in radians for consistency of the units.

So \(\delta \theta = \dfrac{0.1 \pi}{180} \text{ rad} = \dfrac{\pi}{1800} \text{ rad}\). Hence, \[\delta h = 150 \dfrac{\pi}{1800 \times \cos^2\left(\dfrac{2\pi}{9}\right)} \approx 0.45 \text{ m}. \]

So the error in building height resulting from an error in elevation angle of \(0.1^{\circ}\) is about \(0.45 \text{ m}\).
